member.name: T:BT.Core.ADO.ADOCommand
member.summary:
Create a new statement: New ADOCommand("SELECT XXX") Create a multi-statement SQL call:
cSQL = new ADOCommand() cSQL.AddSQL("DECLARE @DT datetime") cSQL.AddSQL("SELECT @DT=MIN(Dt) FROM tblX") cSQL.AddSQL("SELECT * FROM XXX WHERE StartDt>@DT")

member.name: P:BT.Core.ADO.ADOCommand.SQL
member.summary: Getting SQL will return the statement (if you specified more than 1 statement (using AddSQL), then commands are returned separated by ";"+vbcrLf SETING SQL will remove existing statements and replace them with the one you set here. To setup a multi-statement SQL command, use AddSQL instead.

member.name: M:BT.Core.ADO.ADOCommand.AddSQL(System.String)
member.summary: Useful to setup a MULTI STATEMENT SQL call. Most single-statement commands just use the constructor or the SQL property.

member.name: M:BT.Core.ADO.ADOCommand.AddIdTableParameter``1(BT.Core.ADO.IADO,System.String,System.Data.SqlDbType,System.Collections.Generic.List{``0})
member.param: The system will verify that the ADO connection you specify has been setup to allow table parameters.
This function create a temp TABLE variable, and the parameterName parameter will dictate that variable's name (eg - "@values" in the example).
BigTime can guess the SQL type required, but you should supply it if your values and your dbType don't match (eg - string vs integer)
Items to be added to your table parameter (eg - a list of values).

member.name: M:BT.Core.ADO.ADOCommand.VerifyParams
member.summary:
Because the native SQLCommand object is terrible at returning meaningful error messages, we validate parameters using this function so that we can throw a useful error rback to the calling program if parameters aren't valid.
We also use this method to replace Nothing with DBNull.value, to convert EAS.EAGen.EADate values to actual dates and to apply some other standard data logic to all parameters.

member.name: T:BT.Core.ADO.ADOCreate
member.summary: This is the creation factory for all of our ADO objects. Use the appropriate create function to return a new ado connection.
member.remarks:
For the majority of our BigTime functionality, you'll use a tenant-specific ado object (so that tenant filters are applied automatically).
To connect to the BigTime authorization repository, use a master ADO object, and to create a standard database connection that allows you to use all of our built in ado methods, just use a connectionString based ado object. For more details about the functionality provided by these ADO objects, take a look at the IADO interface.

member.name: M:BT.Core.ADO.ADOCreate.ByTenant(BT.Core.BTGlobals.IGlobals)
member.summary: If you have an existing BTGlobals object, then you can use the RepoSource variables to create a tenant-specific ADO object. This provides a few additional functions that standard ADO objects do not (eg - access to binary fields/etc)
member.param: The BTGlobals object that is attached to this tenant instance.

member.name: M:BT.Core.ADO.ADOCreate.ByRepoSource(BT.Core.ADO.IRepoSourceVars)
member.summary: If you have an existing BTGlobals object, then you can use the RepoSource variables to create a tenant-specific ADO object. This provides a few additional functions that standard ADO objects do not (eg - access to binary fields/etc)
member.param: The tenant's RepoSource (VarsList from BTGlobals)

member.name: M:BT.Core.ADO.ADOCreate.ByConnectString(System.String,System.Int64,System.String)
member.summary: This constructor can be used to take advantage of the DB access functionality encapsulated in IADO without relying on the connection string(s) stored in BigTime's configuration or registry settings. If you plan to use this constructor, then you will need to provide a complete SQL connection string.
member.param: e.g. - "Server=EASVR\DB";Database=BIGTIME;User ID=sa;Pwd=pass12!"
60 seconds by default, but you may want to increase that timeout setting if you are going to attempt SQL functions that require more time (eg. - backups)

The default string format for a date is "MM/dd/yyyy," but that format may not work if you are using non-US regional settings. Take a look at the current Thread's regional settings to verify that this format will work.

member.name: P:BT.Core.ADO.ADOBase.ErrorList
member.summary: If the most recent DB function fails, it does not typically return an error. Errors are stored in this ErrorList property instead (so that the calling function can fail gracefully or deal with errors inline)

member.name: P:BT.Core.ADO.ADOBase.RecordLimit
member.summary:
If you set this value to a non-zero number, then any recordset data returned by this object will be limited to the number of rows you specify.
If, for example, the query you are running returns 100000 rows, but RecordLimit is set to 100, then the server will return only 100 rows. Typically, this property is used to "preview" results.

member.name: M:BT.Core.ADO.ADOBase.ExecuteSQLList(System.Collections.Generic.List{BT.Core.ADO.ADOCommand},System.Boolean,System.Boolean)

summary.para: Runs a set of SQL statements (separated by CRLF). Can run a set of statements as a transaction, and can run them one at a time and skip errors. If a line starts with @, then the function is smart enough to know that we are setting a variable value. That variable is then available in the subsequent line, so we can update text files, for example, using a syntax like this:
summary.code: @Bytes="long text value...." UPDATE tblTable SET TextField=@Bytes

member.param: SQL Statement list (as ADO Command objects).
TRUE if this should be run as a transaction
TRUE if each statement should be run without cancelling on error (errors will still be stored in the object's ErrorList property).

member.name: M:BT.Core.ADO.ADOBase.ExecuteSQLList(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)

summary.para: Runs a set of SQL statements (separated by CRLF). Can run a set of statements as a transaction, and can run them one at a time and skip errors. If a line starts with @, then the function is smart enough to know that we are setting a variable value. That variable is then available in the subsequent line, so we can update text files, for example, using a syntax like this:
summary.code: @Bytes="long text value...." UPDATE tblTable SET TextField=@Bytes

member.param: SQL Statement list (separated by CRLF). Note that you can embed ##CRLF## in your SQL statements and this function will read it as a 'newline' when it executes the statement.
TRUE if this should be run as a transaction
TRUE if each statement should be run without cancelling on error (errors will still be stored in the object's ErrorList property).

member.name: T:BT.Core.Crypt.LegacyCipherBase
member.summary: Base class for adapting existing BT cipher algorithms for use in Cipher.Encrypt and Cipher.Decrypt methods. Rather than attempting to fit legacy ciphers into Microsoft's SymmetricAlgorithm, it's handled as a special case in Cipher class. For legacy ciphers, Cipher.Encrypt and Cipher.Decrypt call the abstract EncryptToStream and DecryptFromStream methods defined here.

member.name: M:BT.Core.Crypt.LegacyCipherBase.EncryptToStream(System.String,System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Reads data from InputStream, encrypts it using the Password, then writes results to OutputStream.
member.param: The phrase used to encrypt (and decrypt) the stream. Also known as "Key". Though technically the Key is a byte[] representation of the Password produced by a KeyDerivation algorithm.
A stream of unencrypted bytes.
A stream where the corresponding encrypted bytes will be written.

member.name: M:BT.Core.Crypt.LegacyCipherBase.DecryptFromStream(System.String,System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Reads data from InputStream, decrypts it using the Password, then writes results to OutputStream.
member.param: The phrase used to decrypt (and encrypt) the stream. Also known as "Key". Though technically the Key is a byte[] representation of the Password produced by a KeyDerivation algorithm.
A stream of encrypted bytes.
A stream where the corresponding decrypted bytes will be written.

Indicates if InputStream contained a valid header. If so, the stream was written by the future-proof Cipher API. If not, the stream was written by a legacy cipher API. The value of this parameter affects how the subsequent bytes in the stream are interpreted (as UTF-8, Base64, Hex, etc).

member.name: T:BT.Core.Crypt.CipherName
member.summary: This enum is written to an unencrypted header that appears before the encrypted payload. It is represented as a byte to save space in the header. Do not remove the byte base type or change or remove existing names or numeric values because that will break decryption. It is safe to add names and values.

member.name: T:BT.Core.Crypt.EncryptionHeader
member.summary: Unencrypted header written prior to encrypted payload. Header ensures encrypted data can be decrypted given the password. Do not alter this class. Doing so will break decryption of data written prior to the change, violating the "future-proof" guarantee provided by Cipher.Encrypt and Cipher.Decrypt.

member.name: P:BT.Core.Crypt.EncryptionHeader.Salt
member.summary: For best security, leave null. A random Salt will be generated in Cipher.Encrypt method. This prevents identical plaintexts from producing identical ciphertexts when encrypted using the same key.

member.name: P:BT.Core.Crypt.EncryptionHeader.InitializationVector
member.summary: For best security, leave null. A random InitializationVector will be generated in Cipher.Encrypt method. This prevents identical plaintexts from producing identical ciphertexts when encrypted using the same key.

member.name: M:BT.Core.ActionExtension.RunWithHardTimeout(System.Action,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary:
Use this method to call a synchronous third-party API method that A) Does not accept and honor a cancellation token. B) Is known to block occasionally and never return. This method returns true or false. This method runs the Action on a dedicated thread wrapped in a try catch.
It aborts the thread after timeout has elapsed to protect against runaway CPU usage (such as code stuck in an infinite loop). Aborting a thread is not ideal. The ideal solution is to fix the problematic code that occasionally blocks and never returns. However, if the problematic code is third-party for which we do not have source, we must result to drastic measures to protect our processes.
member.param: The delegate to run on a dedicated thread.
The maximum timespan for which the method is allowed to run before it's aborted.
member.returns: A tuple where Success indicates whether the Func returned in the allotted Timeout (true) or threw an exception or hung (false).

member.name: M:BT.Core.ActionExtension.RunWithHardTimeout``1(System.Func{``0},System.TimeSpan)
member.summary:
Use this method to call a synchronous third-party API method that A) Does not accept and honor a cancellation token. B) Is known to block occasionally and never return. This method either returns T or default(T). This method runs the Func on a dedicated thread.
It aborts the thread after timeout has elapsed to protect against runaway CPU usage (such as code stuck in an infinite loop). Aborting a thread is not ideal. The ideal solution is to fix the problematic code that occasionally blocks and never returns. However, if the problematic code is third-party for which we do not have source, we must result to drastic measures to protect our processes.
member.param: The delegate to run on a dedicated thread.
The maximum timespan for which the method is allowed to run before it's aborted.
member.returns: A tuple where Result is the value returned by Func and Success indicates whether the Func returned in the allotted Timeout (true) or threw an exception or hung (false).

Once that stream is complete it writes to a memory stream and produces a byte array, This can be helpful with converting datatables straight to csv files.

member.name: F:BT.Core.Logger.ELogLevel.Debug
member.summary: Logs that are used for interactive investigation during development. These logs should primarily contain information useful for debugging and have no long-term value.

member.name: F:BT.Core.Logger.ELogLevel.Information
member.summary: Logs that track the general flow of the application. These logs should have long-term value.

member.name: F:BT.Core.Logger.ELogLevel.Warning
member.summary: Logs that highlight an abnormal or unexpected event in the application flow, but do not otherwise cause the application execution to stop.

member.name: F:BT.Core.Logger.ELogLevel.Error
member.summary: Logs that highlight when the current flow of execution is stopped due to a failure. These should indicate a failure in the current activity, not an application-wide failure.

member.name: F:BT.Core.Logger.ELogLevel.Critical
member.summary: Logs that describe an unrecoverable application or system crash, or a catastrophic failure that requires immediate attention.

member.name: F:BT.Core.Logger.ELogLevel.None
member.summary: Not used for writing log messages. Specifies that a logging category should not write any messages.

member.name: T:BT.Core.EAS.EAMerge
member.summary: BigTime frequently merges database or collection data from a recordset into a existing text. We've encapsulated that process into this EAMerge module. Data can be merged into a text file from a recordsource, various collections and each BigTime business objects. Take a look at the ReplaceTags functions in this module for details.

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.EAMerge.GetPropertyValueDeep(System.Object,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Encapsulates REFLECTION for objects, so we can reference a property using a string (e.g. - "TeamList.1.FirstNm")
member.param: An object to examine
The full name of the property to retrieve. Separate "sub-class" names using a period. See detailed documentation for help on using the function to access property names.
Set this to TRUE if you want to return NULL if the property cannot be found through reflection

remarks.para: When classes are created, any properties that are access or set from web pages should be defined as Properties (with a corresponding get/set function). Then, the web page processing engine can use this function to set an object's properties based on the input field's "name" property.

Several objects within the system support "sub-objects" or "collections." The EAProject object, for example, has an EAClient sub-object, and a TeamList collection (a collection of team members) To access those sub items, We use a period-based naming convention (e.g. - TeamList.2.FirstNm will pull the "firstNm" field for the TeamMember object that corresponds to the index value of "1").
Note that this function will return an ERROR if the field you are attempting to access does not exist. The calling function is responsible for dealing with that error.

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.EAMerge.SetPropertyValueDeep(System.Object,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Encapsulates REFLECTION for objects, so we can SET the value of a property using a string for that property's name (e.g. - "TeamList.1.FirstNm")
member.param: An iEAWC object to examine
The full name of the property to set. Separate "sub-class" names using a period. See detailed documentation for help on using the function to access property names.
The value to which this property should be set.

remarks.para: When iEAWC classes are created, any properties that are access or set from web pages should be defined as Properties (with a corresponding get/set function). Then, the web page processing engine can use this function to set an object's properties based on the input field's "name" property.

Several objects within the system support "sub-objects" or "collections." The EAProject object, for example, has an EAClient sub-object, and a TeamList collection (a collection of team members) To access those sub items, We use a period-based naming convention (e.g. - TeamList.2.FirstNm will pull the "firstNm" field for the TeamMember object that corresponds to the index value of "1").

Note that this function will return an ERROR if the field you are attempting to set does not exist or if the value you are passing is invalid for the property. Note that the calling function is responsible for dealing with that error.

member.summary: Called by GetPropertyValue and SetPropertyValue (used to catch/match problems that may come up with overloaded properies.

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.EAMerge.FormatVocab(System.String,BT.Core.ADO.IRepoSource)
member.summary: Call this function to replace VOCABULARY tags with data from a the global vocab list.
member.param: String to merge data into.
BTGlobals.IGlobals objects containing the vocabulary tags to be merged.
member.remarks:
This simple tag replacement routine is meant to quickly merge system vocabulary into strings. For more robust tag replacement, take a look at the MergeRow functions in this object.
For this simple merge, BigTime supports a basic {#vocab} tag. an example of this tag in use is shown below
sText = "The following {#vocab=Project;0} {#vocab=Prj_Task;0}s have not been closed." sText = EAS.EAMerge.FormatTags(sText,_cGlobals)
Using this code, sText will read "The following project tasks have not been closed."
BigTime pulls the values for vocabulary items from the BTGlobals.IGlobals object (in this case, _cGlobals), and it merges them into the text at the appropriate spot.
Note that the merge tag supports a special "format" string. This string takes a 0, 1 or 2 value: 0 is lower-case, 1 is upper-case and 2 is proper-case.

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.EAMerge.FormatTagsForAngular(System.String,BT.Core.BTGlobals.IGlobals)
member.summary: This is a pre-processor that formats a string of text that contains angular-specific replacement tags. It will replace "{{fldNm|date}}" with "{{fldNm||MM/DD/YYYY}}" for example.
member.param: Pass null to this parameter if you would like to use typical US-based date/time and currency formats.

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.EAMerge.MergeVocabAngular(System.String,BT.Core.BTGlobals.IGlobals)
member.summary: Replace simple angular tags with vocab values (eg - {{PROJECT}} becomes "Project")
member.param: Globals object who's vocab is to be used

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.EAMerge.FormatTags(System.String,System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Call this function to replace fld tags with data from an object. String format should contain {#fld=XX} tags.
member.param: String to merge data into.
class object containing the data to be merged.
TRUE if html tags like ampersand and quote should be replaced with their html-safe equivalents.
member.remarks:
The tag replacement process in BigTime is meant to replace simple field values. For more robust tag replacement, take a look at the MergeRow functions in this object.
For this simple merge, BigTime supports a basic {#fld} tag. an example of this tag in use is shown below
sText = "The project {#fld=PrjNm} has {#BudgetRemaining:#,##0.00} dollars remaining." sText = EAS.EAMerge.FormatTags(sText,cHash)
The system will pull values for PrjNm and BudgetRemaining from the EAS.Hashlist(cHash) object and merge them into the text at the appropriate spot.
Note that the merge tag supports a "format" string. Format strings can take any format supported by String.Format. Note that it also implements a "boolean" formatter (eg. - {#fld=BooleanField:1;0} will return a 1 if BooleanField is TRUE and a 0 if it is FALSE).

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.EAMerge.FormatTags(System.String,System.Data.DataRow,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Call this function to replace fld tags with data from a database.
member.param: String to merge data into.
Datarow containing the data to be merged.
TRUE if we should replace ampersands, gt and lt signs and quotes with their html tag equivalent
member.remarks:
The tag replacement process in BigTime is meant to replace simple field values. For more robust tag replacement, take a look at the MergeRow functions in this object.
For this simple merge, BigTime supports a basic {#fld} tag. an example of this tag in use is shown below
sText = "The project {#fld=PrjNm} has {#BudgetRemaining:#,##0.00} dollars remaining." sText = EAS.EAMerge.FormatTags(sText,cDataRow)
The system will pull values for PrjNm and BudgetRemaining from the datarow (cDataRow) object and merge them into the text at the appropriate spot.
Note that the merge tag supports a "format" string. Format strings can take any format supported by String.Format. Note that it also implements a "boolean" formatter (eg. - {#fld=BooleanField:1;0} will return a 1 if BooleanField is TRUE and a 0 if it is FALSE).

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.EAMerge.FormatAngular(System.String,System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Replace angular style moustache tags with data from an object (expression should contain {{FldNm|Fmt}} style tags.
To evaluate mathematical expressions, wrap the expression with square brackets e.g. {{[0.1*FldNm]}}.
member.param: The original expression to evaluate (the string that contains the tags).
The object whose field values are used as tag values
TRUE to remove/replace html unsafe characters (eg - so these results can be merged in to XML)

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.EAGen.EvalExp(System.String)
member.summary:
Evaluates SIMPLE expressions (operator prescedence is ignored) as are parens. Supports CEILING; FLOOR; IIF; +, --, *, and /.
Used primarily in custom invoice line item creation.
member.returns: For a more complete expression evaluator, use the Evaluator object in the library.
member.remarks:
CEILING: CEILING(x,y). Return X if X<Y. Otherwise, return Y.
CEILING: CEILING(x,y). Return X if X>Y. Otherwise, return Y.
IIF: IIF(bool,x,y). Return X if bool==true. Otherwise, return Y.

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.EAGen.EXP_Evaluate(BT.Core.BTGlobals.IGlobals,System.Int64,System.String,System.Collections.IDictionary,System.Collections.IDictionary,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Replaces variable tags in an expression with values from the database or from the user's settings. Syntax for a paramter is <#PARAMTYPE=PARAMNAME;DefaultValue> and ParameterType can be:
#G_VAR (Globals.VarList properties); #SETTING (GlobalSetting - eg: iis.VarNm); #cPROP / #VAR (dictionary values),
#VOCAB (system vocabulary value); #UID (the StaffSID value), #ISPERMIT (0/1 for user permission; format= PERMITSET.PERMITID),
#URL (full base-url of the BigTime site)
member.param: Valid EAGlobals object
The user's StaffSID value
The Expression to evaluate
a collection of session-specific properties (#PROP values)
a collection of session-specific properties (#VAR values)
TRUE if the system should not insert spaces before/after each replaced clause.

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.XML.GetSubValue(System.Xml.XmlElement,System.String,System.String,System.Xml.XmlNamespaceManager)
member.summary: Retrieves the item text from a specified node.
member.param: The XMLElement to query
Element name to locate
Sub element name (if appropriate) or attribute name.
If the XML contains namespace definitions, then an nsmanager will be needed to read values.
member.returns: Returns an empty string if the element isn't found.

remarks.para: If the item isn't found with a simple SelectNode, then the method adds descendant-or-self:: to the element name.
if the p_sElName_sub parameter begins with @, then the method assumes you are looking for an attribute value.

member.name: M:BT.Core.EAS.XML.GetSubValueXML(System.Xml.XmlElement,System.String,System.String,System.Xml.XmlNamespaceManager)
member.summary: Retrieves the INNERXML from within a specified node.
member.param: The XMLElement to query
Element name to locate
Sub element name (if appropriate) or attribute name.
If the XML contains namespace definitions, then an nsmanager will be needed to read values.
member.returns: Returns an empty string if the element isn't found.

remarks.para: While this method is similar to the GetSubValue element, this method returns the full XML of the node you are searching for (as a string).
If the item isn't found with a simple SelectNode, then the method adds descendant-or-self:: to the element name.
if the p_sElName_sub parameter begins with @, then the method assumes you are looking for an attribute value.

member.name: T:BT.Core.RandomThreadSafe
member.summary: Prefer to use the RandomThreadSafe2 class, which is safe for use in async concurrent code.
member.remarks: This class relies on a ThreadStatic attribute, which does not play well with the Task Parallel Library and async / await. Async client code that references RandomThreadSafe may start on one thread and continue on another. This thread switch may occur at any await statement. See Stephen Cleary's comment at https://stackoverflow.com/a/26519250/8992299. See Marc Gravell's comment at https://stackoverflow.com/a/13010688/8992299.
